Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story: The phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was sweeping up after my last appointment. I glanced at the screen—my best friend’s name flashed, and when I answered, her voice was shaky. Her car had broken down on the highway, and she was stranded, scared, and needed me right away. My heart lurched; of course, I wanted to drop everything and go to her. But as I hung up, the bell above the salon door jingled. A young woman stepped in, eyes wide and uncertain, clutching her purse. She was my next client, a first-timer, and I could see the anxiety in her posture. I knew how important it was to greet her warmly, to make her feel safe and welcome, especially since she’d confessed over the phone how nervous she was about getting her hair cut. I stood frozen, torn between the urgent need of my friend and the professional promise I’d made to this client. My mind raced, guilt and worry tangling together as I tried to figure out what to do next.
